input_text:
Listen, I know we're bleeding cash on this price war with Competitor X. 
Every time we drop our subscription fee by $5, they match it. We're both 
making 40% less revenue than we were a year ago. Ideally, we'd both just 
raise our prices back to the standard market rate tomorrow. But if we 
raise ours and they keep theirs low, we lose 90% of our customers overnight. 
I suspect they feel the exact same way. So, unless we can get a guarantee 
they will hike prices too (which is illegal collusion),...
game_description: Classic PD structure where mutual cooperation (raising prices) benefits both, but unilateral defection (keeping prices low while competitor raises) creates massive advantage. Both trapped in mutually destructive equilibrium.

payoff_matrix.T: 90% market share if you keep prices low while competitor raises
payoff_matrix.R: Both return to standard market rates with normal profit margins
payoff_matrix.P: Both stuck at rock-bottom prices with 40% revenue loss
payoff_matrix.S: Lose 90% of customers if you raise prices while competitor stays low

revealed_preferences: Avoid being the sucker who raises first
player_a.interpretation: Stated and revealed preferences align - genuine desire to escape PD trap but rational fear of unilateral cooperation

player_b.interpretation: Actions show identical strategic position - trapped in same PD structure

deception.stated_game: Prisoners_Dilemma with mutual recognition of trap
deception.revealed_game: Prisoners_Dilemma with mutual recognition of trap
cheap_talk_indicators: 'Ideally we'd both raise prices' - costless statement of preference
credible_signals: Continued participation in price war despite losses
deception.analysis: No deception detected. Speaker honestly acknowledges the structural trap and legal constraints preventing coordination.

verbal_cooperation: 'Ideally, we'd both just raise our prices back to the standard market rate'
action_defection: Every time we drop our subscription fee by $5, they match it
Both keeping prices at rock bottom

confidence.reasoning: Clear PD payoff structure: T(90% market share) > R(normal profits) > P(40% loss) > S(lose 90% customers). Both words and actions align perfectly with PD analysis.

equilibrium.outcome: Continued mutual defection (low prices) despite both preferring cooperation
equilibrium.reasoning: Nash equilibrium at mutual defection. Neither player can unilaterally improve by raising prices due to massive customer loss risk.

risk.sensitivity: Continued value destruction for both companies until one exits market or finds alternative solution
risk.reasoning: Unsustainable 40% revenue loss will eventually force market consolidation or business model changes

prescription.mechanism: Price leadership, market segmentation, or regulatory intervention to enable coordination
prescription.lever_variable: T - Reduce temptation payoff through differentiation or increase switching costs
prescription.player_a_advice: Differentiate product to reduce price sensitivity, build switching costs, or seek non-price competitive advantages
prescription.player_b_advice: Same strategic advice - escape pure price competition through differentiation
prescription.mediator_advice: Industry association could facilitate non-collusive coordination mechanisms or government could modify antitrust interpretation
prescription.victim_warning: No victim - both players trapped in mutually destructive equilibrium
